question: Question_03_(d)
statement:
Suppose we are given 4 points (\emph{x}\textsubscript{1},
\emph{y}\textsubscript{1}), (\emph{x}\textsubscript{2},
\emph{y}\textsubscript{2}), (\emph{x}\textsubscript{3},
\emph{y}\textsubscript{3}) and (\emph{x}\textsubscript{4},
\emph{y}\textsubscript{4}) in the plane and we want to find a function
\emph{$f$(x)}, defined for $x_1 \leq x \leq x_4$, whose graph interpolates
these points. Assume that

\begin{align*}f(x) = \begin{cases}
p_1(x) & \text{for } x_1 \leq x \leq x_2 \\
p_2(x) & \text{for } x_2 \leq x \leq x_3 \\
p_3(x) & \text{for } x_3 \leq x \leq x_4
\end{cases}\end{align*}

where each \emph{p}\textsubscript{i}(\emph{x}) is a polynomial.

\textbf{(d)} When each \emph{p}\textsubscript{i}(\emph{x}) is a cubic
polynomial of the form

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
a_i(x-x_1)^3 + b_i(x-x_i)^2 + c_i(x-x_i) + d_i\end{align*}

the equations written in parts
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_03_(a)}{(a)},
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_03_(b)}{(b)}
and
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_03_(c)}{(c)}
above are equivalent to a system of linear equations in the unknowns
\emph{a}\textsubscript{i}, \emph{b}\textsubscript{i},
\emph{c}\textsubscript{i} and \emph{d}\textsubscript{i}, \emph{i} = 1,
2, 3. How many more equations are needed if there are to be the same
number of equations as unknowns? What equations are usually added and
why?
sols:
In
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_03_(a)}{part
(a)} we were asked to find the different equations that can be drawn
from the condition that $f(x)$ goes through all the given points. This
yielded the following 6 equations:

\begin{align*}
p_{1}(x_{1}) &= y_{1}\\
p_{1}(x_{2}) &= y_{2}\\
p_{2}(x_{2}) &= y_{2}\\
p_{2}(x_{3}) &= y_{3}\\
p_{3}(x_{3}) &= y_{3}\\
p_{3}(x_{4}) &= y_{4}\end{align*}

In
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_03_(b)}{part
(b)} we were then asked to find the equations that can be found from the
condition that the function, $f(x)$, was also first order
differentiable. This yielded 2 more equations:

\begin{align*}
p'_{1}(x_{2}) &= p'_{2}(x_{2})\\
p'_{2}(x_{3}) &= p'_{3}(x_{3})\end{align*}

This same method can be applied in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_03_(c)}{part
(c)} to find the conditions that the function is second order
differentiable yielding 2 more equations:

\begin{align*}
p''_{1}(x_{2}) &= p''_{2}(x_{2})\\
p''_{2}(x_{3}) &= p''_{3}(x_{3})\end{align*}

Therefore, we were able to find 10 equations in total using the
conditions set forth in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_03_(a)}{(a)},
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_03_(b)}{(b)},
and
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_03_(c)}{(c)}.
However, we have three polynomials and each of these polynomials have 4
unknowns ($a_{i}$, $b_{i}$, $c_{i}$, and $d_{i}$ ; $i=1,2,3$), so we
have a total of 12 unknowns that we need to solve for. It follows that
we would need 2 more equations in order to have the same number of
equations as unknowns.

These equations are usually prescribed depending on the context of the
problem. The usual condition is that the second derivative values at the
endpoints should be 0. Thus, the last 2 equations that we need are:

\begin{align*}
p''_{1}(x_{1}) &= 0\\
p''_{3}(x_{4}) &= 0\end{align*}
hints:
Count the number of equations that we gathered in this question so far.
How many unknowns do we have in total?

The usual additional equations involve the second derivative at the
endpoints.
